{{Infobox non-profit | name = '''The Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence (OFAI)''' | image = | caption = | founder = | type = | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = 1984 | location = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | coordinates = | origins = | director = | key_people = Director [[Robert Trappl|Prof. Robert Trappl]]
[[Paolo Petta]]
[[Harald Trost]]
[[Gerhard Widmer]]
[[Brigitte Krenn]] | area_served = | products = | services = | focus = [[Artificial intelligence]] | mission = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | motto = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|www.ofai.at}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence''' ([[German language|German]]: '''Ö'''sterreichisches '''F'''orschungsinstitut für '''A'''rtificial '''I'''ntelligence - '''OFAI''') is an Austrian non-profit contract [[research institute]]. OFAI is a research institute of the [[Austrian Society for Cybernetic Studies]] (Österreichische Studiengesellschaft fuer Kybernetik - OSGK), a registered [[scientific society]] founded in 1969. ==History== The Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence was founded in 1984 with support from the [[Austrian Federal Ministry for Science and Research]]. Since its inception, OFAI has been headed by its director, Prof. [[Robert Trappl]]. == Research == Currently, 28 specialists, mainly computer scientists and linguists, all graduates from universities, work as employees at OFAI, plus 9 scientists, mainly professors at universities, on a contractual base. OFAI basic and applied research is performed in several areas of [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]], most notably: * [[Language Technology]] * Interaction Technologies * [[Neural Computation]] and [[Robotics]] * Intelligent Music Processing and [[Machine Learning]] * Intelligent Software Agents and New Media * AI and Society. ==External links== * [http://www.ofai.at Official website of the institute] ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{citation|url=http://www.portal.ac.at/owa/portal.details_en?ogn_id_in=1626 |accessdate=2012-11-04 |title=Akademisches Portal Österreich |work=Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence (ÖFAI) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060809024356/http://www.portal.ac.at/owa/portal.details_en?ogn_id_in=1626 |archivedate=2006-08-09 |df= }} {{citation |url=http://dl.acm.org/inst_page.cfm?id=1032530 |accessdate=2012-11-04 |title=ACM Digital Library |work=Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence}} }} [[Category:Research institutes in Austria]] {{Austria-org-stub}} {{sci-org-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox artist | name = Cas Oorthuys | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Casparus Bernardus Oorthuys | birth_date = November 1, 1908 | birth_place = [[Leiden]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1975|07|22|1908|11|01}} | death_place = [[Amsterdam]] | nationality = Dutch | spouse = {{marriage|November 1, 1908
|1932|1938|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Lydia Krienen
|1940}} | field = Photography | training = School for Architecture, Decorative Arts and Art Crafts, [[Haarlem]] | movement = The New Photography, De Ondergedoken Camera | works = ''Amsterdam tijdens den hongerwinter'' | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = 1964 ANWB Prize
1966 CPNB prize
1971 decorated, Knight of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] | elected = | website = }} '''Casparus Bernardus Oorthuys''' (November 1, 1908 – July 22, 1975), known as Cas, was a Dutch photographer and designer active from the 1930s until the 1970s.{{Citation | author1=Auer, Michèle | author2=Auer, Michel | title=Encyclopédie internationale des photographes de 1839 à nos jours = Photographers encyclopaedia international 1839 to the present | publication-date=1985 | publisher=Editions Camera obscura | isbn=978-2-903671-06-8 }} ==Education== Casparus Bernardus (Cas) Oorthuys, born 1908 in [[Leiden]], was the fourth child and first son of Dorothea Catherina Helena Christina de Stoppelaar (1875-1948) and Reverend Gerardus Oorthuys (1876-1959), who started his career as a pastor in [[Brakel]]. In 1909 the family moved to [[Amsterdam]] where from 1921 Oorthuys attended the [[Amsterdams Lyceum|Amsterdam Lyceum]] for three years before enrolling in the technical school in the Timorplein in Amsterdam. From 1926-30 he studied architecture at the School for Architecture, Decorative Arts and Art Crafts in [[Haarlem]] and, after the closure of this school in 1927, in the architecture department of the Haarlem MTS, during which time he joined the free-thinking Dutch Association of Abstinent Students, and first took up photography. ==Career== In 1930 Oorthuys joined the municipality of Amsterdam as a [[structural engineer]] and was involved, among other things, in the design of the market halls on the [[Jan van Galenstraat metro station|Jan van Galenstraat]]. In 1932 he, with many others, lost his job as a result of the [[Great Depression|economic crisis]]. Unemployed, he came into contact with the [[Communist Party of the Netherlands|Communist Party of Holland]], which he joined. Oorthuys sought work as a graphic designer and photographer and with the painter [[Jo Voskuil]] started an advertising agency OV 20 ("Oorthuys-Vos 20") from 1932 to 1935. Oorthuys was involved with and a member of various left-wing organisations in his field. In 1936 he became permanent photographer at [[De Arbeiderspers]]. He produced photography and graphics for [[Communism|communist]] and [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] organisations and in the tradition of "workers' photography" he documented poverty, police violence, the unemployed, homeless people and evictions for magazines, book illustrations and book covers and exhibitions.Ensel, R. (2003). Hollandse Heimat: nationalisme en de fotografie van het landschap in het Interbellum.Henkes, B. (2005). Personalities. Groniek (168). ==Resistance work during WW2== During the war Oorthuys helped forge identity papers and photographed clandestinely for the Underground Camera to document the activities of the [[Reichskommissariat Niederlande|German occupiers]], and also the awful [[Dutch famine of 1944–45|Hongerwinter]], the Dutch Famine of 1944/45. During the postwar recovery he recorded the [[Nuremberg trials|Nuremberg war crimes trials]] and the rebuilding of his homeland. On August 5, 1938 Oorthuys had divorced teacher Gezina Broerse (1910-1997) whom he had married on August 31, 1932 and with whom he had two children. He married scriptwriter Lydia Krienen on April 3, 1940, just before the war broke out in May.[https://www.trouw.nl/home/-cas-was-geen-lolbroek-~ad0d95e4/ Marie Louise Schipper, 'Cas was geen lolbroek': interview with Lydia Oorthuys, Trouw, December 1, 1998] During the Occupation, Oorthuys became involved in the Personal Identification Centre established in 1942 and made passport photos for fake ID cards, while earning a bare living on an assignment from Contact publishing company for a book about agriculture.{{Citation | title=Agriculture in the Netherlands / text by D. J. Maltha ; photographs by Cas oorthuys | author1=Maltha, D. J | author2=Netherlands. Ministerie van Landbouw en Visserij | publisher=Contact Pub. Co | language=English }}Kuitert, L. (2010). Publishing House Contact and Its Support for Authors in the Second World War. Quaerendo, 40(3-4), 305-326. In May 1944, when he took ration cards to the architect J.J. van der Linden and others in hiding, he was arrested by the Germans and imprisoned in camp [[Amersfoort concentration camp|Amersfoort]].Simpelaar, L. (2016). Capturing time. Trade journal Social Work , 17 (4), 23-23. Unexpectedly, he was released again in August, presumably at the interposition of [[Nico de Haas]] who, despite having been with Oorthuys one of the founders in 1936 of the ‘photo and film’ group of the Association for the Defense of Cultural Law (BKVK) in preparation of the anti-fascist exhibition De Olympiade Onder Dictatuur (DOOD),Langfeld, G. (2007). German Art in The Netherlands before and after World War II. Avant Garde Critical Studies, 21, 157. had quickly worked up to become a prominent Dutch SS man after the German invasion. On release Oorthuys connected with De Ondergedoken (‘Underground’) Camera,Tjepkema, A., & Walvis, J. (1985). Ondergedoken, het ondergrondse leven in Nederland tijdens de Tweede Wereldoorlog. De Haan formed around [[Dolle Dinsdag]] on the initiative of the German emigrant Fritz Kahlenberg and the former soldier Tony van Renterghem; ‘Underground’ because the Nazi occupiers declared a complete ban on “photographing, filming, drawing, and displaying persons and things in any other way outside of domestic spaces” from November 20, 1944. The group photographed in any way they could, keeping cameras concealed and shooting 'from the hip'; consequently the quality of the imagery is distinguished by its haphazard nature; often with tilted, uncentered framing and other accidental effects. Their aim was initially to document the Allies’ liberation which was longer in coming than hoped, and instead they recorded a severe winter of hunger and resistance in photos that have become the image of the German occupation,{{Citation | author1=Bool, Flip | author2=Asser, Saskia | title=A critical history of photography in the Netherlands : Dutch eyes | publication-date=2007 | publisher=Waanders ; [Amsterdam] : Photography in the Netherlands Foundation | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8318055}} especially Cas Oorthuys’ picture of a woman with a piece of bread in close-up. A variation was published on the cover of ''Amsterdam tijdens den hongerwinter'' (‘Amsterdam During the Winter of Hunger’) published by Contact / De Bezige Bij, in 1947,{{Citation | author1=Parr, Martin | author2=Badger, Gerry | title=The photobook : a history | publication-date=2004 | page= 188, 196 | publisher=Phaidon | isbn=978-0-7148-4285-1 }} while the now more famous image from this series reached an audience of 9 million through the 1955 exhibition and publication ''[[The Family of Man]].''Popular Photography, Nov 1996, Vol. 60, No. 11, page 11, ISSN 1542-0337{{Cite book | author1=Steichen, Edward | author2=Steichen, Edward, 1879-1973, (organizer.) | author3=Sandburg, Carl, 1878-1967, (writer of foreword.) | author4=Norman, Dorothy, 1905-1997, (writer of added text.) | author5=Lionni, Leo, 1910-1999, (book designer.) | author6=Mason, Jerry, (editor.) | author7=Stoller, Ezra, (photographer.) | author8=Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.) | title=The family of man : the photographic exhibition | publication-date=1955 | publisher=Published for the Museum of Modern Art by Simon and Schuster in collaboration with the Maco Magazine Corporation | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/10809600 }}{{Citation | author1=Hurm, Gerd, 1958-, (editor.) | author2=Reitz, Anke, (editor.) | author3=Zamir, Shamoon, (editor.) | title=The family of man revisited : photography in a global age | publication-date=2018 | publisher=London I.B.Tauris | isbn=978-1-78672-297-3 }}{{Citation | author1=Sandeen, Eric J | title=Picturing an exhibition : the family of man and 1950s America | publication-date=1995 | publisher=University of New Mexico Press | edition=1st | isbn=978-0-8263-1558-8 }}{{Citation|author1=Slager, Henk|title=The photographic paradigm|page=163|publication-date=1997|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-0187-9|author2=Balkema, Annette W}} == Post-war == After the war Oorthuys had maintained the left-wing convictions{{Citation | author1=Warren, Lynne | title=Encyclopedia of twentieth-century photography | publication-date=2006 | page=1149 | publisher=Routledge | isbn=978-1-57958-393-4 }} that had prompted his joining the worker-photographer movement Vereeniging van Arbeiders-Fotografen in 1932,Jay, B. (1993). Album: A Memoir. History of Photography, 17(1), 1-9. and with his equally idealistic friends Carel Blazer, [[Eva Besnyö]], and [[Emmy Andriesse]],{{Citation | author1=Roosens, Laurent | author2=Salu, Luc, 1948- | title=History of photography : a bibliography of books | publication-date=1989 | publisher=Mansell | page=7 | isbn=978-0-7201-2310-4 }} formed the Vereniging van Beoefenaars der Gebonden Kunsten, the GKf, on September 1, 1945. In keeping with his convictions, from January until March 1947, Oorthuys, accompanied by his writer the educationalist Albert de la Court, travelled through Java and Borneo in Indonesia commissioned by ABC-Press and the publishing house Contact. In July 1947 the resultant book ''Een staat in wording'' (A Nascent State), promoted a peaceful solution to the Indonesian struggle for independence, and reviews reveal its impact on changing attitudes to the colony as the Netherlands tried to re-exert its control,Beb Vuijk, 'De Republik Indonesia: een staat in wording', In De Vrije Katheder, June 25, 1947. but before the book appeared, a [[Indonesian National Revolution|violent revolution]] was in full swing. From 1945-75 he produced numerous books and reports on the post-war reconstructionKempers, B. (1998). De sociale esthetiek van de wederopbouw. Amsterdams Sociologisch Tijdschrift, 25(1), 94-98. in Dutch industry, agriculture, regions and cities and undertook reportage in [[Indonesia]] (1947),Oorthuys, C., & Poeze, H. (2010). Een staat in wording; fotoreportage van Cas Oorthuys over het Indonesië van 1947. Bijdragen Tot De Taal-, Land- En Volkenkunde, 166(1), 175.{{Citation | author1=Wijaya, Taufan | title=Foto jurnalistik dalam dimensi utuh | publication-date=2011 | publisher=Sahabat | edition=Cet. 1 | isbn=978-979-029-726-5 }} photographed the Peace Conference in Paris (1948), and in 1950 produced reportage in [[Western New Guinea|West Irian]]."No photographer so much embodies 20th century Dutch reportage photography as Cas Oorthuys." {{Citation | author1=Amsterdam (Netherlands). Stedelijk Museum | author2=Visser, Hripsimé | title=100 x photo : 100 photographs from the collection of the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam | publication-date=1996 | publisher=Stedelijk Museum ; Bussum : Thoth | isbn=978-90-6868-147-5 }} With Lydia, Oorthuys had three children; sisters Fenna and Hansje, and the youngest a son, Frank, born in 1960. Photography became a family concern; during the summer holidays from 1951 they traveled to make 28 photo pocketbook in a series for Contact-Photo books, starting with ''Bonjour Paris'' with a cover by Jan van Keulen, each on a different country, promoting tourism for a now more prosperous Dutch population.{{Citation | author1=Crawford, Sally (Sally Elizabeth Ellen), (editor.) | author2=Ulmschneider, Katharina, (editor.) | author3=Elsner, Jaś, (editor.) | title=Ark of civilization : refugee scholars and Oxford University, 1930-1945 | publication-date=2017 | publisher=Oxford University Press | edition=First | isbn=978-0-19-968755-8 }} The compact books were designed around the square format of the Rolleiflex that Oorthuys favoured and several were marketed by foreign publishers in English, French and German language editions. During this period he also designed five postage stamps (1951) and two more in 1964. On each of the five stamps, a portrait of a child, among them his own daughter Hansje, is montaged against the background of a typical aspect of the Netherlands, showing the (housing) construction and industry. For the Belgian Ministry of Information he covered the Congo in 1952,Creemers-Palmers, M. (1992). Tentoonstelling "Cas Oorthuys - Guaranteed Real Dutch - Congo" (Book Review). Afrika Focus, 8(2), 151. with further reports on cattle raising in [[Jersey]] (1954), followed by stories on [[Socialist Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Serbia]] and [[Spain]] (1955) ==Awards and legacy== [[File:SamkaldenOorthuys1971.jpg|thumb|Oorthuys decorated with Knight of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] in 1971]] * 1964 ANWB Prize for the book ''Amsterdam onze hoofdstad'' * 1966 CPNB prize for the book ''Netherlands'' * 1969 the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam|Sledelijk Museum]], Amsterdam, marks Oorthuys' 60th anniversary with an exhibition and book * 1971 decorated, Knight of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] * 1975 postage stamp commemorating the anniversary of liberation Oorthuys died unexpectedly on July 22, 1975 in Amsterdam, at the age of 66, having only three months earlier designed a postage stamp on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the Liberation. At the end of his career he left 500,000 pictures, a huge archive faithfully maintained by his wife Lydia who until she was in her seventies sold its imagery to a variety of clients before she donated the entire collection to [[Netherlands Photo Museum|Nederlands Fotomuseum]]. ==Exhibitions== ===Solo exhibitions=== * 1969: Stedelijk Museum, Amsterdam (NL) * 1970: ''Portraits'', Haags Museum, Den Haag (NL) *1970: Hoogovens (NL) * 1970: Psychologisch Laboratory, Nijmegen (NL) *1970: Kontrasten, Haags Museum, Den Haag (NL) * 1970: ''Mensen-People'', In de Prinsetun, Leeuwarden (NL) * 1970: Kunstcentrum, Berge (NL) * 1974: Oalerie Fiolet, Amsterdam (NL) * 1975: Amsterdam Historisch Museum, (NL) * 2003: 1 Aug – 16 Aug, ''Cas Oorthuys'', Saló Juvenil-Biblioteca (ES) * 2003: 6 Sep – 28 Sep, ''Cas Oorthuys'', Sala Plens de l'Ajuntament de Petra (ES) * 2003: 13 Nov – 4 Dec, ''Cas Oorthuy''s, Sala d'exposicions del Roser (ES) * 2003/4: 12 Dec – 4 Jan, ''Cas Oorthuys'', Casal de ca s'Hereu (ES) * 2004: 28 May – 29 Aug, ''Cas Oorthuys'', foam Fotografiemuseum, Amsterdam (NL) * 2006: 18 Jan – 5 Mar, ''Fotografías Madrid, Mayo 1955; Cas Oorthuys'', Fundación Carlos de Amberes (ES).Oorthuys, C. B., Schierbeek, L. R., & De Sterck, G. (2005). Madrid, mayo 1955: Cas Oorthuys. Real Diputación San Andrés de los Flamencos, Fundación Carlos de Amberes. * 2007: 20 Feb – 19 Dec, ''Fotografías Madrid, Mayo 1955; Cas Oorthuys'', Fundación Carlos de Amberes (ES). ===Group exhibitions=== * 1937 Stedelijk Museum, Amsterdam (NL) * 1953 Museum of Modern Art, New York (US) * 1954 ''Subjektive Fotografie 2'', Saarbriicken (DE) * 1957 ''Biennale di Fotografia'', Venezia (IT) *1971 ''Mensen-People'', Meyhuis, Helmond (NL) * 1971: ''Mensen-People'', Moscow (USSR) * 1979 Haags Oemeentemuseum, Den Haag (NL) * 2002/3: 10 Nov – 12 Jan, ''Zwarte Rook: Fotografie en steenkool in de twintigste eeuw'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2003: 20 Sep – 19 Oct ''60 Exhibitions: Breda Photo,'' Breda Photo (NL) *2003: 29 Aug – 26 Oct, ''Rare Snuiters'', De Nieuwe Kerk (NL) * 2003/4: 19 Oct – 18 Jan, ''Licht, lucht en ruimte - Wonen in de jaren vijftig: Cas Oorthuys Jan Versnel, De Zonnehof'' - centrum voor moderne kunst (NL) * 2004: 7 Feb – 13 Mar, ''Onbedoelde Fotografie'', ACF Amsterdams Centrum voor Fotografie (NL) * 2003/4: 12 Dec – 23 May, ''Foto's van Vijftig'', Stedelijk Museum De Lakenhal (NL) * 2004: 18 Sep – 5 Dec, ''Wegkijken: Foto's uit het Spaarnestad'' Fotoarchief, De Hallen (NL) * 2004/5: 4 Sep – 9 Jan, ''Paris was great!: Dutch photographers in Paris 1945-1965'', Stedelijk Museum Schiedam (NL) * 2005: 10 Feb – 22 May, ''La Photographie à l'épreuve'', IAC - Institut d'art contemporain (FR) * 2005: 14 May – 12 Jun, ''Made in Holland'', Dexia FotoFestival Naarden: * 2005: 22 May – 11 Sep, 1945 - ''Im Blick der Fotografie. Kriegsende und Neuanfang'', LWL-Museum (DE) FotoFestival NaardenNL * 2006: 8 Sep – 3 Dec ''The Street: Pioneers of 20th-Century Photography from the Rijksmuseum's photo collection'', Van Gogh Museum (NL) * 2007: 19 Apr – 26 Aug, ''Dutch Eyes'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2008: 22 Mar – 22 Jun, ''The Van Zoetendaal Collection'', Fotomuseum Den Haag (NL) * 2014: 14 Sep 2013 – 5 Jan, ''White: Photography, Art, Design, Fashion, Film'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2015: 5 Feb – 14 Mar, ''Mid-Century Dutch: Vintage Photographs by Dutch Artists'', Keith de Lellis Gallery (US) * 2015: 24 Jan – 24 May, ''Rotterdam in the Picture: 175 Years of Photography in Rotterdam'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2016: 16 Mar – 19 Jun, ''Strange and Familiar: Britain as Revealed by International Photographers, curated by Martin Parr,'' Barbican Art Gallery (GB) * 2017: 9 Sep 2016 – 22 Jan, ''Der Rhein und die Fotografie 2016-1853'', LVR LandesMuseum Bonn (DE) * 2017: 25 Nov 2016 – 29 May, ''Strange and Familiar: Britain as Revealed by International Photographers, Curated by Martin Parr,'' Manchester Art Gallery (GB) * 2017: 20 May – 20 Aug, ''Spring Tide: Van Zoetendaal & The Collection'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2017: 20 May – 3 Sep, ''Spring Tide: Van Zoetendaal & The Collection'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * 2018: 3 Mar – 23 Sep, ''From Muscle Power to Robot Resistance'', Museum Helmond (NL) * 2018: 20 Jan – 9 Dec, ''The Collection Illuminated by Charlotte Dumas: Oorthuys with Martien Coppens, Richard Tepe and Ed van der Elsken'', Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) *2019, 15 Sep 2018 – 13 Jan,''The Mix | Dutch Photographers: Past & Present,'' Netherlands Photo Museum (NL) * Ongoing: ''The Family of Man, UNESCO Memory of the World, Steichen Collections,'' Clervaux Castle (LU) ==Publications== *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | title=The Netherlands : seen by the tourist = Nederland : zoals de toerist het ziet | publication-date=1947 | publisher=Contact | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/31030926}} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, C. | author2= Brusse, J. | title= Bonjour Paris, bonsoir Paris, au revoir Paris: Parijse begroetingen | publication-date=1951 | publisher=Contact }}{{Citation | author1=Frizot, Michel | author2=Centre national du livre (France) | title=Nouvelle histoire de la photographie | publication-date=1994 | page=574 | publisher=A. Biro : Bordas | isbn=978-2-04-019976-0 }} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, C.| author2=Cocheret, C. A.| author3=Aero-photo Nederland| publication-date=1952 | title=This is Rotterdam | publisher=Contact }}{{Citation|author1=Frizot, Michel|title=Nouvelle histoire de la photographie|page=626|publication-date=1994|publisher=A. Biro : Bordas|isbn=978-2-04-019976-0|author2=Centre national du livre (France)}} * {{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | title=This is Brussels and the World Exhibition | publication-date=1958 | publisher=Cassirer | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/34801189}} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | title=Het laatste jaar, 1944-45 : een verslag in foto's over onderdrukking en bevrijding | publication-date=1970 | publisher=Contact | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/28234855}} * {{Citation | author1=Vries-Kruyt, T. de | author2=Kretschmar, Vivienne van | author3=Oorthuys, Cas | title=Small ship, great sea : the life story of a mongoloid boy | publication-date=1971 | publisher=Collins | isbn=978-0-00-460201-1 }} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Alings, Wim | title=Mensen. : People. Een fotoboek/A book of photographs van Cas Oorthuys | publication-date=1969 | publisher=Contact | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/31878834}} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Alings, Wim | title=Peoplevan Cas Oorthuys.English approximations by James Brockway | publication-date=1969 | publisher=Contact | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/5340214}} * {{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | title=Oxford in focus | publication-date=1981 | publisher=Cassirer | isbn=978-0-85181-100-0 }} * {{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | title=Guaranteed real Dutch, Congo | publication-date=1992 | publisher=Uitgeverij Duo/Duo | isbn=978-90-72971-11-1 }} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Thys van den Audenaerde, Dirk F. E | author3=Creemers-Palmers, M | title=Mensen aan de stroom : reisimpressies van Cas Oorthuys in Belgisch-Kongo, 1959 : foto-album | publication-date=1992 | publisher=Museum-Tervuren | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/28455887}} * {{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Bool, Flip | author3=Raaff, Henk | title=Cas Oorthuys : Amsterdam | publication-date=2004 | publisher=B. Lubberhuizen | isbn=978-90-5937-063-0 }} * {{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Jong, Joop de | author3=Mulder, Toni | author4=Suermondt, Rik | title=Cas Oorthuys, onderweg : Europa, 1945-1965 | publication-date=2001 | publisher=Contact Amsterdam | isbn=978-90-254-6321-2 }} *{{Citation | author1=Oorthuys, Cas | author2=Vriens, Jacques, (author.) | author3=Kleijwegt, Gerrit, (translator.) | title=Allemensen! = everyman! | publication-date=2000 | publisher=Rotterdam Stichting Uitgeverij Duo/Duo | isbn=978-90-72971-57-9 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://collectie.nederlandsfotomuseum.nl/nl/de-fotografen/weergave/record?id=4afd7a72-d4bb-104e-7755-0bd19e21e9b1 Oorthuys' works in the collection of the Nederlands Fotomuseum] [[Category:Dutch photographers]] [[Category:Travel photographers]] [[Category:Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch photojournalists]] [[Category:World War II]] [[Category:Resistance members by nationality]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of Orange-Nassau]] [[Category:War photographers]] [[Category:Photography in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Photography in Indonesia]] [[Category:Communists by nationality]] [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]]

{{Infobox airline | airline = Cronos Airlines |image=| IATA = C8{{cite web | url=http://www.ch-aviation.com/portal/airline/CNS | title=Cronos Airlines | work=[[ch-aviation]] | accessdate=29 January 2017}} | ICAO = CRA | callsign = CRONOS | aoc = | hubs = [[Malabo International Airport]] |focus_cities=| frequent_flyer = | alliance = | fleet_size = 5 | destinations = 6 | company_slogan = | parent = |num_employees=| logo = Cronos logo.png | logo_size = 250 | alt = | founded = 2007 | commenced = | ceased = | bases = | lounge = | subsidiaries = | headquarters = [[Malabo]], [[Equatorial Guinea]] | key_people = Andreas Kaïafas, CEO http://www.worldfolio.co.uk/region/africa/equatorial-guinea/andreas-kaiafas-ceo-of-cronos-airlines-equatorial-guinea-n1616{{cite web|title=Airline's rise contributes to development take-off|url=http://www.theworldfolio.com/interviews/andreas-kaiafas-ceo-of-malabo-based-cronos-airlines-equatorial-guinea-n2509/2509/|website=The Worldfolio|publisher=The Worldfolio|accessdate=20 September 2016}} | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | profit = | assets = | equity = | website = {{URL|cronosair.com}} }} '''Cronos Airlines''' is a [[regional airline]] headquartered in [[Malabo]], [[Equatorial Guinea]]. Cronos Airlines is a passenger and cargo carrier based at [[Malabo International Airport]] in [[Equatorial Guinea]]. It operates a service in [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Cameroon]], [[Benin]] and [[Nigeria]].{{cite web|title=Cronos Airlines|url=http://centreforaviation.com/profiles/airlines/cronos-airlines-c8|website=CAPA Center for Aviation|publisher=CAPA|accessdate=20 September 2016}} ==History== Cronos Air was founded in 2007 by its CEO, Andreas Kaïafas.{{Cite web|url=http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_public/airlines/airlines-equatorialguinea/cronos.htm|title=Airlines based in Equatorial Guinea: Cronos Airlines|website=www.airlineupdate.com|access-date=2017-09-13}} It started operations in 2008, Cronos was created in 2008, with a small 19-seater and a license to operate for six months. It was a provisional license. They came back with a 30-seater at the end of 2009 and by July 2010 they had a 92-seater, the BA-146, which was operating in Germany before with [[Eurowings]]. They later acquired a second 98-seater and a 'certificado de transporte aéreo' (air transport certificate).{{cite web|title=Airline's rise contributes to development take-off|url=http://www.theworldfolio.com/interviews/andreas-kaiafas-ceo-of-malabo-based-cronos-airlines-equatorial-guinea-n2509/2509/|website=The Worldfolio|publisher=The Worldfolio|accessdate=20 September 2016}} ==Destinations== Cronos Airlines operates the following services ({{as of|2016|2|19|lc=on}}): *{{flag|Benin}} **[[Cotonou]] - [[Cadjehoun Airport]] *{{flag|Cameroon}} **[[Douala]] - [[Douala International Airport]] *{{flag|Equatorial Guinea}} **[[Bata, Equatorial Guinea|Bata]] - [[Bata Airport]] **[[Malabo]] - [[Malabo International Airport]] **[[Mengomeyén]] *{{flag|Nigeria}} **[[Port Harcourt]] - [[Port Harcourt International Airport]] **[[Lagos]] - [[Murtala Muhammed International Airport]] *{{flag|Ghana}} **[[Accra]] - [[Kotoka International Airport]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsghana.com.gh/cronos-airlines-commences-commercial-flight-to-accra/|title=Cronos Airlines Commences Commercial Flight To Accra|last=Admin|date=2016-10-31|newspaper=News Ghana|access-date=2017-02-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/business/2016/October-31st/cronos-airlines-starts-operations-in-ghana.php|title=Cronos Airlines starts operations in Ghana|last=Myjoyonline.com|date=2016-10-31|access-date=2017-02-19|language=en-US}} *{{flag|Niger}} **[[Niamey]] - [[Diori Hamani International Airport]] ==Fleet== The Cronos Airlines fleet consists of the following aircraft (as of August 2016):{{cite journal|title=Global Airline Guide 2016 (Part One)|journal=Airliner World|issue=October 2016|page=13|accessdate=14 October 2016}}
{| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse;text-align:center" |+ '''Cronos Airlines fleet''' |- style="background:#22659c;" ! rowspan="2" style="width:180px;" | Aircraft ! rowspan="2" style="width:80px;" | In Service ! rowspan="2" style="width:30px;" | Orders ! colspan="2" | Passengers ! rowspan="2" | Notes |- style="background:#22659c;" ! style="width:25px;" | Y ! style="width:25px;" | Total |- |[[British Aerospace 146#BAe 146-200 and Avro RJ85|BAe 146-200]] |1 (as of August 2017){{cite journal|title=Global Airline Guide 2017 (Part One)|journal=Airliner World|issue=October 2017|page=13|accessdate=29 September 2017}} |— |82 |82 |{{cite web|url=http://www.cronosair.com/about/our-fleet/ |title=Our Fleet|publisher=Cronos Aviation|access-date=2017-07-04}} |- ||[[British Aerospace 146#BAe 146-300, Avro RJ100, and RJ115|BAe 146-300]] |1 |— |92 |92 | |- |[[Embraer ERJ 145 family#Civilian models|Embraer ERJ 135LR]] |3 |— |37 |37 | |- |- !Total !5 !0 !colspan="3"| |}
===Historical fleet=== Cronos Airlines has previously operated the following aircraft: * 1 [[British Aerospace 146|BAe 146-300A]] * 1 [[Airbus A319|Airbus A319-100]]{{cite web|url=https://www.planespotters.net/airline/Cronos-Airlines/historicFleet |title=Cronos Airlines Historic Fleet|website=Planespotters|access-date=2017-07-04}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Aviation}} *{{Official website|http://www.cronosair.com/}} [[Category:Airlines of Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2007]] [[Category:Equatoguinean companies established in 2007]] {{EquatorialGuinea-stub}} {{africa-airline-stub}}

revision.text:
{{for|the rugby union and rugby league footballer who played in the 1890s, and 1900s|Dicky Goddard}} {{Infobox person |name = Dick Goddard |image = Dick Goddard at Humane Society Event.jpg |imagesize = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1931|2|24}}<ref name=pd80th>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Dawidziak |coauthors= |title=WJW Channel 8 weatherman Dick Goddard turns 80 Feb. 24, celebrates 50 years on TV in May |url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2011/02/wjw_channel_8_weatherman_dick_goddard_turns_80_feb_25_celebrates_50_years_on_tv_in_may.html |work=[[The Plain Dealer]] |publisher= |date=2011-02-23 |accessdate=2011-02-26 }}</ref> |birth_place = [[Akron, Ohio]], U.S. |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = former [[television news]] [[wikt:weatherman|weatherman]], [[meteorologist]], [[author]] |nationality = [[Americans|American]] }}
'''Richard D. "Dick" Goddard''' (born February 24, 1931) is a former American television [[meteorologist]], [[author]], [[cartoonist]], and animal activist. For over five decades, he served as the evening meteorologist at [[WJW (TV)|WJW-TV]], the [[Fox Broadcasting Company]]-affiliated television station in [[Cleveland, Ohio]]. He holds the [[Guinness Book of World Records|Guinness World Record]] for longest career as a weather forecaster.<ref name="guinnessworldrecords.com">[http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-career-as-a-weather-forecaster Longest career as a weather forecaster - Guinness World Records]</ref>
==Biography== After graduating from [[Green High School (Green, Ohio)|Green High School]]<ref>[http://fox8.com/author/dickgoddardfox8news/ Dick Goddard]. ''Fox8.com''. Retrieved on 2012-04-26.</ref> in what is now [[Green, Ohio]], in 1949,<ref>WJW-TV, "Fox 8 News at 10" broadcast, 2009-08-12 (personal mention of 60th Reunion).</ref> Goddard began his weather career while taking classes on meteorology during a stint with the [[United States Air Force]] from 1949 through the early 1950s.<ref name=pd80th/> During this time, Goddard's most notable assignment was forecasting for atmospheric nuclear weapons tests by the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission]] in the Pacific.<ref name=pd80th/>
He then attended [[Kent State University]], where he majored in drama and broadcasting. While there he had notable success as the lead character, Curly, in the school's production of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s ''[[Oklahoma!]]''
After graduating from Kent State in 1960,<ref>{{cite journal|first=Ashley |last=Katona |last2= |first2= |year=Winter 2011 |title=Dick Goddard, '60 |journal=Kent State Magazine |volume=10 |issue=1 |page=28 |publisher= |doi= |url=http://www.glpublishing.com/digitaleditions/KENT111/pageflip.html |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711101836/http://www.glpublishing.com/digitaleditions/KENT111/pageflip.html |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }}</ref> he joined the weather team at [[Westinghouse Broadcasting]]-owned [[WKYC|KYW-TV]] (now WKYC-TV) in Cleveland a year later; while at KYW-TV, Goddard worked alongside [[sports commentator|sports anchor]] [[Jim Graner]].<ref name="WKYC History PDF">{{cite web|year=2010|title=History of WKYC-TV 1948-2010|url=http://www.wkyc.com/company/about_us/history_of_wkyc.pdf|work=[[WKYC|WKYC.com]]|publisher=WKYC-TV, Inc|accessdate=August 25, 2010|quote=1961: ... The news team consisted of anchors Carl Stern and Bud Dancy, weathercaster Dick Goddard and sports talent [[Jim Graner]].|format=PDF}}</ref> Goddard was one of several employees of KYW-TV who agreed to move to [[KYW-TV|WRCV-TV]] in [[Philadelphia]] in June 1965, after Westinghouse was allowed by the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] to reverse a station trade with [[NBC]] in 1956 based on coercion in order for Westinghouse to retain their NBC affiliations; the KYW calls also moved back to Philadelphia. However, Goddard did not take a liking to Philadelphia, and returned to Cleveland several months later. In 1966, Goddard became the chief meteorologist at WJW-TV, where he would work for the remainder of his career.<ref name=pd80th/>
After returning to Cleveland, Goddard also took a job with the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Cleveland Browns]] as the team's official [[statistician]] for home games. Then a CBS affiliate, WJW carried Browns games at the time as part of their NFL play-by-play contract until the 1970 [[AFL-NFL merger]] (due to the Browns move to the AFC), at which point the games moved to WKYC – this was a key factor in his having joined the station. He held this position from 1966 to 2011, with the exception of a three-year period from 1996–1999 when the franchise was suspended [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy|as the old Browns franchise moved to]] [[Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore]] and Cleveland was given a new team.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dick Goddard retires...from Browns broadcast booth |url=http://www.wtam.com/cc-common/news/sections/newsarticle.html?feed=122520&article=10400329 |publisher=[[WTAM|WTAM-AM]] |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2012-09-10 }}</ref>
From August 1977 to January 1979, Goddard also hosted WJW's version of ''[[Bowling for Dollars]]'', a syndicated franchised game show. He has also appeared in numerous skits on WJW's popular ''[[Big Chuck and Lil' John]] Show'' over the years, and does occasional stage work.<ref>[http://video.aol.com/video-detail/wjkw-tv8-cleveland-bowling-for-dollars-promo-1978/3768522838 WJKW-TV8 - Cleveland - "Bowling for Dollars" Promo - 1978 - AOL Video<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In honor of Goddard's 50 years on Cleveland TV, most of which was spent at WJW, the portion of South Marginal Road (the southern frontage road of the [[Cleveland Memorial Shoreway]]) in front of the WJW studios was renamed "Dick Goddard Way" on May 23, 2011.<ref name = "DGW">{{cite news |first=Lindsay |last=Buckingham |coauthors= |title=S. Marginal Road Dedicated to FOX 8's Own Dick Goddard |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/topic/wjw-dick-goddard-way-dedication-ceremony-txt,0,7997084.story |work= |publisher=WJW-TV |date=2011-05-23 |accessdate=2012-04-26 }}<!-- URL leads to unrelated news outlet but text is intact from original page --></ref>
{{As of|2014}} Goddard resided in [[Medina Township, Medina County, Ohio|Medina Township, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Knox |title=Dick Goddard rescued while second man climbs tree to avoid waters |url=http://medinagazette.northcoastnow.com/2014/05/13/photos-man-rescued-climbing-tree-avoid-mondays-flood-waters/ |work=[[Elyria-Lorain Broadcasting Co.|The Medina Gazette]] |date=2014-05-13 |accessdate=2014-12-10 }}</ref>
In December 2014, at age 83, Goddard signed a "multi-year" contract renewal with WJW.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Dawidziak |title=Dick Goddard signs new multi-year deal with Channel 8 |url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2014/12/dick_goddard_signs_new_multi-year_deal_with_channel_8.html |work=The Plain Dealer |date=2014-12-09 |accessdate=2014-12-10 |quote=Although Channel 8 would not disclose specific terms of the new contract, the station did confirm it was a multi-year deal. }}</ref> On May 18, 2016, Goddard announced that he would retire from his weather duties in November 2016, while continuing his animal advocacy and remaining host of the Woollybear Festival.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cunningham|first=Kaily|title=Dick Goddard announces retirement: 'In November, I’m stepping away from the weather maps'|url=http://fox8.com/2016/05/18/dick-goddard-announces-retirement-in-november-im-stepping-away-from-the-weather-maps/|publisher=WJW-TV|date=2016-05-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Mark|last=Dawidziak|url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2016/05/channel_8s_dick_goddard_ending_55-year_run_as_weatherman_in_november.html|title=Channel 8's Dick Goddard ending 55-year run as weatherman in November|work=The Plain Dealer|date=2016-05-18|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> He delivered his last forecast on the station on November 22, 2016, with the station's weather center renamed for him. He will continue to tape animal advocacy and adoption segments for WJW.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2016/11/dick_goddard_says_tearful_goodbye_to_55-year_career_as_a_cleveland_weather_forecaster.html|title=Dick Goddard says tearful goodbye to 55-year career as a Cleveland weather forecaster|last=Dawidziak|first=Mark|date=22 November 2016|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref>
==The Woollybear Festival== {{Main|Woollybear Festival}} In 1973 Goddard created the first Woollybear Festival, a day-long family event dedicated to teaching children about the weather, family fun, and animals. Some of the events include a caterpillar race, animal costume contests, and musical performances.
==Advocacy== Goddard has been an outspoken opponent of animal abuse.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Zinni |title=Activists Announce 'Goddard's Law' to Protect Animals |url=http://fox8.com/2013/04/01/activists-announce-goddards-law-to-protect-animals/ |publisher=WJW-TV |date=2013-04-01 |accessdate=2013-10-01 }}</ref> "Dick Goddard's Law", a bill to increase the severity of penalties for abuse, was introduced into the [[Ohio General Assembly]] in 2013<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Zinni |title='Goddard's Law' Gets More Support to Crack Down on Animal Abuse |url=http://fox8.com/2013/09/30/goddards-law-gets-more-support-to-crack-down-on-animal-abuse/ |publisher=WJW-TV |date=2013-09-30 |accessdate=2013-10-01 }}</ref><ref>[http://archives.legislature.state.oh.us/bills.cfm?ID=130_HB_274 H.B. No. 274, Ohio 130th General Assembly]</ref> and reintroduced in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.legislature.ohio.gov/legislation/legislation-summary?id=GA131-HB-60|title=H.B. No. 60, Ohio 131st General Assembly|quote=Section 3. This act shall be known as Dick Goddard's Law.}}</ref> The 2015 version was signed into law on June 13, 2016.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Kasich Signs Eight Bills |url=http://governor.ohio.gov/MediaRoom/PressReleases/TabId/200/ArticleId/444/language/en-US/kasich-signs-eight-bills-6-13-16.aspx|date=2016-06-13|publisher=[[List of Governors of Ohio|Governor of Ohio]], [[John Kasich|John R. Kasich]]|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref>
==Awards and honors== *[[American Meteorological Society]] Seal of Approval (#45)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ametsoc.org/memdir/seallist/get_listoftv.cfm |title=AMS List of TV Seal Holders |publisher=Ametsoc.org |date=2013-12-29 |accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref> *2011 Gold Circle Award, presented by [[Lower Great Lakes Emmy Awards]] chapter<ref name="LGL Awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.nataslgl.org/awards_circles.php |title=NATAS Lower Great Lakes Chapter |publisher=Nataslgl.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref> *1992 Silver Circle Award, presented by Lower Great Lakes Emmy Awards chapter<ref name="LGL Awards" /> *Cleveland Press Club Journalism Hall of Fame Inductee (class of 2001)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pressclubcleveland.com/hall-of-fame-archives.aspx |title=The Press Club of Cleveland |publisher=Pressclubcleveland.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref> *Ohio Broadcasters Hall of Fame Inductee (class of 1989)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://broadcastershalloffame.com/year.htm |title=Broadcasters Hall of Fame |publisher=Broadcasters Hall of Fame |date= |accessdate=2014-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302120526/http://www.broadcastershalloffame.com/year.htm |archivedate=2014-03-02 |df= }}</ref> *Cleveland Association of Broadcasters Hall of Fame Inductee (class of 1994)<ref>http://www.cabcleveland.com/CAb_Cleveland/Hall_of_Fame.html</ref> *South Marginal Road in Cleveland renamed "Dick Goddard Way"<ref name = "DGW" /> *Ohio GA 131 House Bill 60 named "Dick Goddard's Law" *[[Guinness Book of World Records]] - Longest career as a weather forecaster (51 years, 6 days)<ref name="guinnessworldrecords.com"/> *Fox 8 News weather desk renamed the "Dick Goddard Weather Center"<ref>[http://www.fox8.com/2016/11/22/fox-8-honors-dick-goddard-with-the-newly-named-dick-goddard-weather-center Dick Goddard Weather Center - Fox 8.com (WJW-TV)]</ref> *Annual event established by Goddard renamed the "Dick Goddard [[Woollybear Festival]]"<ref>[http://vermillionchamber.net/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/WB-2017-costume-and-500-race-ad.jpg 2017 Dick Goddard Wooleybear Festival ad]</ref>
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title=Six Inches of Partly Cloudy: Cleveland's Legendary TV Meteorologist Takes on Everything–and More |first=Dick |last=Goddard |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2011 |publisher=Gray & Co |series= |location=Cleveland |isbn=978-1-59851-066-9 |pages= }} *{{cite book |title=Dick Goddard's Almanac for Northeast Ohio |first=Dick |last=Goddard |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |publisher=Gray & Co |series= |location=Cleveland |isbn=1-886228-92-2 |pages= }} (Also published 2002–2004) *{{cite book |title=Dick Goddard's Weather Guide for Northeast Ohio |first=Dick |last=Goddard |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1998 |publisher=Gray & Co |series= |location=Cleveland |isbn=1-886228-12-4 |pages= }}
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |title=Big Chuck: My Favorite Stories from 47 Years on Cleveland TV |first=Chuck |last=Schodowski |authorlink=Big Chuck and Lil' John |coauthors= |year=2008 |publisher=Gray & Co |series= |location=Cleveland |isbn=978-1-59851-052-2 |pages= }}
==External links== *"[http://www.grayco.com/cleveland/authors/goddard-dick/author.shtml About Dick Goddard]" ''Gray & Company'' website.

{{for|a football club with a similar name|FC Electroputere Craiova}} {{Infobox company | name = Electroputere S.A. | logo = | caption = | image =File:ND3-0001 manufacturer info board.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | type = [[Public company|Public]]: ({{BVB|EPT}}) | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1949}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = | location = [[Craiova]], [[Romania]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Railroad
Power Generation | products = [[Locomotives]]
[[Electric motors]]
[[OEM|OEM parts]] | services = Locomotive maintenance
Locomotive management
Training | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.electroputere.ro/en/ electroputere.ro] | footnotes = | intl = }} [[File:Bușteni-train-station2008g.jpg|thumb|5100 kW [[CFR Class EA|CFR Class 41]] Electric locomotive currently in operation by Romanian CFR]] '''Electroputere S.A.''' (which translates as ''Electropower'' in English) is a company based in [[Craiova]], [[Romania]]. Founded in 1949, it is one of the largest industrial companies in Romania. Electroputere has produced more than 2,400 [[diesel locomotive]]s, and 1,050 [[electric locomotive]]s for the Romanian, Bulgarian, Chinese, and Polish railways, additionally producing other urban vehicles and complex equipment.{{cite web |title=Electroputere Craiova - Manufacture |url=http://www.electroputere.ro/en/P/production.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090404091034/http://www.electroputere.ro/en/P/production.php |archivedate=2009-04-04 |df= }} ==Products== Electroputere are currently manufactures of: * Industrial electrical parts - [[circuit breaker]]s, [[transformer]]s etc. * Industrial [[electric motor]]s & Converters * Heavy duty power [[transformer]]s * [[Railway]] and [[Tram|Urban vehicles.]] They also have divisions specialising in: * [[Forging]] and [[Molding (process)|molding]] metal * Equipment repairing * Tools modernisation. ==Electric and diesel-electric locomotives== {{See also|List of Electroputere locomotives}} ===Export orders=== [[File:56003 at Cheltenham Racecourse.JPG|thumb|right|[[British Rail Class 56]] locomotives were built by Electroputere and [[British Rail Engineering Limited]]]] A total of 1,105 locomotives were delivered between 1972—1991 to railway companies in the following countries: *{{Flagicon|Bulgaria}} Bulgaria *{{Flagicon|China}} China *{{Flagicon|Greece}} Greece *{{Flagicon|Iran}} Iran *{{Flagicon|Poland}} Poland *{{Flagicon|UK}} United Kingdom *{{Flagicon|Yugoslavia}} Yugoslavia [http://christianferoviarul.blogspot.com/2008/11/locomotive-exportate-de-sc.html Exports between 1972-1991] One of its more notable foreign orders was for the [[British Rail Class 56|Class 56]] locomotives for [[British Rail]]. The 30 locomotives were outsourced to Electroputere because [[Brush Traction]] could not build them at its own plant; however, upon their arrival in the UK, the machines were deemed to be unsuitable for use, as they suffered from poor construction standards, and had to be withdrawn and extensively rebuilt. (However, they were seen as being perfectly reasonable for use in Romania by the Romanian crews who tested them)"'The Locos that Came in From the Cold" ''[[The Railway Magazine]]'' (December 2000/January 2001 issues) ==See also== * [[Căile Ferate Române|Romanian Railways - Căile Ferate Române]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Electroputere}} *[http://www.electroputere.ro/en/ Electroputere official site (in English)] *[http://www.derbysulzers.com/cfr2100.html CFR 2,100hp Co-Co Locomotive] *[http://www.zf.ro/zf-24/electroputere-o-privatizare-esuata-cu-distrugere-de-valoare-industriala-cine-raspunde-11480907] [[Category:Electroputere]] [[Category:1949 establishments in Romania]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1949]] [[Category:Locomotive manufacturers of Romania]] [[Category:Companies of Romania]] [[Category:Organizations based in Craiova]] [[Category:Privatized companies in Romania]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Bucharest Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Romanian brands]] {{manufacturing-company-stub}} {{Romania-stub}} {{Europe-company-stub}}

page.title: Honored Teacher of the Republic of Belarus

revision.comment: /* History */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: its' → its using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Honored Teacher of the Republic of Belarus''' ({{lang-ru|Заслуженный учитель Республики Беларусь}}) is one of many official titles presented by the [[Government of Belarus|Government]] of [[Belarus]]. The purpose of the award is to honor teachers at all educational levels for their work in educating the youth of [[Belarus]]. The title was created by decree in 1995 and is awarded with a badge and a diploma.
== History == The title was a carry over from the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, where citizens of various professions were honored by the national and subnational governments for their long contributions to a specific field or to the nation. When it was part of the Soviet Union as [[Byelorussia SSR]], had titles of their own to award their citizens. One those titles was "Honored Educator of the Byelorussia SSR" ({{lang-ru|Заслуженный учитель БССР}}). When Belarus left the Soviet Union in 1991, the awarding of the title was scrapped. The return of the title, with its present name, occurred with the passage of [[Resolution (law)|Resolution]] N 3726-XII, titled "System of State Awards for the Republic of Belarus," on April 13, 1995.
== Criteria == To qualify for the award, a Belarusian teacher must have been teachering for fifteen or more years and the quality of the education must be above the normal standards required by the state. The teacher can be from any level of schooling and from any type of school, regardless if it is owned by the state or by private institutions. Home school teachers can also qualify for the award.
== Badge == The medallion at the bottom of the badge consists of an oak wreath and a shield. On the shield, the rank of "Honored Teacher" is written in Russian. At the top part of the badge, a metal plate is inscribed with the name of the country in Russian. The a red ribbon is placed about the plate. The top plate is 20x18 millimeters and the bottom medallion is 24 mm in diameter.
== External links == *Bel Awards.com [http://www.belawards.narod.ru/PZaslUchitel.htm Information on the title]
[[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of Belarus]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 605 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1991-055A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1991-055A|title=INTELSAT 6 F-5|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=13 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 21653 | mission_duration = 13 years (planned)
{{frac|17|1|2}} years (achieved) | spacecraft_bus = [[HS-389]] | manufacturer = [[Hughes Aircraft|Hughes]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|4296|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|14 August 1991, 23:15:13|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4|Ariane 44L]] V45 | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]] | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|January 2009}} | orbit_epoch = 13 September 1991 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35756|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35818|km}} | orbit_inclination = 0 degrees | orbit_period = 1436.11 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''[[Intelsat VI]]'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 604|Intelsat VI F-4]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 701|Intelsat VII F-1]] (Intelsat VII) }} '''Intelsat 605''', previously named '''Intelsat VI F-5''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1991, it was the fourth of five [[Intelsat VI]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat VI series was constructed by [[Hughes Aircraft]], based on the [[HS-389]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat 605 was launched at 23:15:13 UTC on 14 August 1991, atop an [[Ariane 4]] 44L carrier rocket, flight number V45.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[ELA-2]] at [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} and placed Intelsat 605 into a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. The satellite raised itself into its final [[geostationary orbit]] using two liquid-fuelled [[R-4D-12]] engines,{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-6.htm|title=Intelsat-6 (601, 602, 603, 604, 605)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=13 July 2012}} with the satellite arriving in geostationary orbit on 20 August 1991.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/geo.date|title=Index|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Geostationary Orbit Catalog|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} Intelsat 605 initially operated in a geostationary orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|35756|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|35818|km}}, and 0 degrees of [[inclination]].{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} The satellite carried 38 IEEE [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and ten IEEE {{Ku band}} [[transponder]]s, and had a design life of 13 years and a mass of {{convert|4296|kg}}. During late 1991, Intelsat 605 was operated at a longitude of 21.5 degrees west. In July 1992, it was placed at 24.5 degrees west, where it operated until November 1997. It subsequently operated at 27.5 degrees west from December 1997 to March 2003; 32.9 degrees east from April 2003 to October 2004; 77 degrees west from December 2004 to January 2005, and 174 degrees east from April 2005 to January 2009. It was placed into a [[graveyard orbit]] and decommissioned in January 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_605.html|title=Intelsat 605|publisher=tbs Internet|work=The Satellite Encyclopedia|date=3 July 2012|accessdate=13 July 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1991}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1991]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]]

[[Kibushi Ndjate Wooto]] | music = Griot Tetela Djamba Yodi Shongo }} '''''Kinshasa Septembre noir ''''' is a 1992 film directed by [[Jean-Michel Kibushi]]. == Synopsis == The children of Kinshasa, using pencils and recycled paper, tell what they remember about the terrible plundering the soldiers carried out in the city on September 23, 1991, when "they killed for pleasure". == References == {{Reflist}} {{RefFCAT|790}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=5960062}} [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo films]] [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed films]] {{DRCongo-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox shopping mall | shopping_mall_name = Mall of Montenegro | image = | image_width = 280px | caption = | location = {{flagicon|Montenegro}} [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]] | address = | coordinates = {{Coord|42.432061|19.262686|display=title}} | opening_date = September 23, 2010 | closing_date = | developer = | manager = | owner = Gintaş | number_of_stores = | number_of_anchors = | floor_area = 58,000 m² | floors = 3 | parking = | website = http://www.mallofmontenegro.com/ | footnotes = }}
'''Mall of Montenegro''' is a shopping mall located in the [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]].
The mall is a complex featuring covered [[marketplace]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20100612061524/http://www.green-bazaar.co.me/ Green Bazaar]), a [[Ramada]] hotel, and the shopping mall itself. The entire complex was built on the location of former open marketplace, as a [[public–private partnership]] between [[Podgorica Municipality]] and [[Turkey|Turkish]] company of [https://web.archive.org/web/20101008015730/http://www.gintas.com.tr/eng/index.asp Gintaş].
The mall is located on ''Bratstva i Jedinstva'' street, which is also main north/south thoroughfare of Podgorica, and is a part of [[European route E65|E65]]/[[European route E80|E80]] European routes. The entire complex has total floor area of 58,000 m², while [[gross leasable area]] of the shopping mall is 17,000 m².
Besides ''Green Bazaar'', which is a natural [[anchor tenant]], a large [[Mercator (retail)|Mercator]] [[supermarket]] is the largest tenant. Prominent stores in the mall include [[Levi Strauss & Co.]], [[Sergio Tacchini]], [[Office Holdings|Office Shoes]], [[Intersport]] and others. The mall also features a [[bowling]] alley, cafés, a fast food court, children's playground, and entertainment park. An underground parking garage serves the entire complex.
Although it is the largest shopping mall in Podgorica, in gross built area terms, it has had constant problems with vacancy since its opening, as [[Delta City]] shopping mall has already saturated the small Montenegrin market, and has a stronger presence of international clothing brands. Thus, Delta City is currently considered a more high end shopping mall.
==See also== *[[Delta City#Delta City Podgorica|Delta City]]
==External links== * http://www.mallofmontenegro.com/ - Official Web Site (Montenegrin and English)
{{Podgorica}} {{Shopping malls in the Western Balkans}}
[[Category:Shopping malls established in 2009]] [[Category:Podgorica]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Podgorica]] [[Category:Shopping malls in Podgorica]]
{{Montenegro-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox Union |name= CNSLR-Frăţia |country= [[Romania]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[ETUC]] |members= 800,000 |full_name= National Confederation of Free Trade Unions of Romania - Brotherhood |native_name= Confederaţia Naţională a Sindicatelor Libere din România-Frăţia |image= [[Image:CNSLR logo.png]] |founded= 1993 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Bucharest]], Romania |people= [[Marius Petcu]], president
[[Sorin Stan]], secretary general |website= [http://www.cnslr-fratia.ro cnslr-fratia.ro] |footnotes= }} The '''National Confederation of Free Trade Unions of Romania – Brotherhood''' ({{lang-ro|Confederaţia Naţională a Sindicatelor Libere din România-Frăţia}} or {{lang|ro|CNSLR-Frăţia}}) is the largest [[national trade union center]] in [[Romania]]. It was created from the 1993 merger of the National Confederation of Free Trade Unions of Romania (CNSLR) and [[Frăţia (union)|Frăţia]]. The CNSLR is the reformed organization of previous [[Communist Romania|communist era]] unions. Membership has declined to its current level of 800,000, but it is still by far the largest of the trade union centers in the country. CNSLR-Frăţia is affiliated with the [[International Trade Union Confederation]], and the [[European Trade Union Confederation]]. ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} ==External links== *[http://www.cnslr-fratia.ro CNSLR-Frăţia official site] {{Portal|Organized labour}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Confederation of Free Trade Unions of Romania - Brotherhood}} [[Category:1993 establishments in Romania]] [[Category:International Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:National trade union centers of Romania]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1993]] {{Romania-stub}} {{Europe-trade-union-stub}}
